title: Let's kill run
body:
In order to run a Flask application during development we have the `.run()` method or with 1.0 `flask run`. While both are convenient they are a bad idea.

First of all their naming implies that, they are used for running a Flask application, they aren't. They are for running a Flask application during development, a subtle but important difference that causes significant confusion. Apart from that though, running a Flask application is never what you want.

Instead you want to _develop_, _test_ or _deploy_ an application. While development and testing can imply running a web server, running a web server during development means something different than running a web server during testing. In deployment you don't actually want to run your application at all, you should let a web server do that.

So far we kind of allow people to signal their intent with DEBUG and TESTING, but this needs to be explicitly configured by every user and issues such as #1049, show that this is not without issues.

Therefore what I would like to propose is to create three commands `develop`, `test` and `deploy`. These commands should be extendable through extensions and users. It should be easily possible to use different configurations for these scenarios.  Extensions that are only helpful during development like Flask-Debugtoolbar could activate/deactivate themselves based on intent, Flask-Migrate could perform migrations during development and extensions dealing with assets could start background threads monitoring the file system for changes during development. It would further simply clear up a lot of confusion for newcomers.

Running flask with either of these commands should by default set `DEVELOPMENT` (for backwards compatibilty also DEBUG but let's remove that, the name is awful), `TESTING` or `DEPLOYMENT` respectively and issue a signal. Furthermore `develop` should run the development server as `run` does now. `test` and `deployment` shouldn't actually test or deploy the application as we don't want to enforce a specific test runner or deployment solution. Instead the user should be implement these, if so desired. Nevertheless they would be useful as they establish convention extensions can rely on.

I realize that such a change is probably somewhat controversial (which is why this is not a pull request), it would also distinguish us significantly from Django, which works like Flask does now. Nevertheless I think it would be a great idea and I'm curious what others think of this idea. So, thoughts?

comments_inline.body: The only point i strongly agree with is that `run` needs to be renamed. Adding new methods and config keys sound like a nice idea, but i am not much more than +0 on those, though I'd prefer if we had a single `STAGE` config key whose value is from `{'TESTING', 'DEPLOYMENT', 'DEVELOP'}`. But that's just a detail.

I agree with renaming from `run` to something else.  I was thinking of having a `develop` command already which implies `--debug` by default.  The reason I did not want to actually go down that route was that there is no direct built-in answer of what "run" then means.  Maybe there should be a clear story that says how to go to production beyond what we have in the docs.

I think we should consider recommending gunicorn/uwsgi + nginx. This is widely used, fast and recommended by almost anyone you ask anyway.

It would also open up the possibility to extend the tutorial with a section on deployment which I think a lot of people would appreciate.

Just to add my two cents into this topic, could we just add something a long the lines of `app.develop.run()` or `app.develop.start()` It would probably be clear and you could also add more methods and functionality under it relating to develop.
-1 for `deploy`. The deploy doc is better.

The deploy doc definitely and very obviously isn't better. It's useful but we regularly have people that don't get that the development server is intended for just that: development. Especially in the last few days we had a lot of people with issues related to this. There is a mailing list discussions going on about how Flask is insecure because the development server isn't secure.

Even if you don't agree with my entire proposal, the documentation is obviously not good enough and run a bad name.

When i use Flask, I subclass Flask and make a start() method that handles configuration.
I think it's more straightforward than having 3 commands.
+1 to improve the docs. Need to clarify proper architecture for production enviroments

**+1** to:
- Improving docs with examples of proven, fast, and efficient deployment setups.
- Renaming .run() to something that expresses the development state and enables or disables certain portions of the configuration based upon the object.

Is there really anyone who is running a server with flask `run()` in production? I am -1 on creating more commands on this topic. Instead, we can print a message on `run()`, for exampe, **You should not use flask run in production**.

Deployment is a big topic. It is not just about how to run a web server, but also how to manage your machines. For small teams, a `fabric` would be enough. But if you have too many machines, you should use something like saltstack or ansible.

I'd +1 on improving documentation. The project creators should read the documentation well. If someone is running a flask `run()` in production, he is not taking it seriously. Why should we?

I thought some more about this, and while I am still +1 on renaming `run`, I now agree with @lepture and think that Flask should **not** mandate a development workflow as proposed in the OP.

The warning sounds like a good idea, but I think it would be highly annoying most of the time. Maybe Flask should warn when used on port 80. This information should not be won through the arguments passed to `run_simple`, but the WSGI environment, which takes reverse proxies into account.
@untitaker Yeah. Warning on port 80 is a good idea. If someone is using a proxy server like Nginx, he would have the knowledge on deployment.

> If someone is using a proxy server like Nginx, he would have the knowledge on deployment.

I am not sure about that. Some web frameworks (esp. outside of Python) have builtin servers that are meant to be reverse-proxied to. People might assume the same here.

By the way it might be interesting to consider replacing the development server entirely. I've seen several discussions around that in the case of Django where some people would like Django to use gunicorn. As far as I can tell, the only reason that hasn't happened, yet, is that gunicorn doesn't support windows, yet.
Not sure. How do these servers cope with the Werkzeug debugger?
@DasIch I don't like the idea to bundle gunicorn in a web framework. Documentation is a good way to point out the differences between development and production.

Hi, just perusing the list of 1.0 issues and found this. Thought I would take 5 and send in a PR for it.

I prefer the simple approach of always printing a short warning when `run()` is used, then making it easy for the app developer to find the docs on using a production WSGI server. Not renaming preserves compatibility, but also gives us the opportunity to point people in the right direction in the form of the warning.

Thanks for Flask!

`run` and `develop` are both bad choices, because all it does is `serve_http` or `serve_http --debug`

for anything that has grown you need caches, redis, queues, maybe celery and lots and lots of services to actually tun it
Maybe naming it `runlocal`. To me this communicates it'll run the web app but it's meant for local use only.
I like @RonnyPfannschmidt proposal for `serve_http [--debug]`. Alternatively something similar to what @Auha proposed: `app.(web)server.start()`.
`app` should no longer have the method

+1

I'm with @DasIch's proposal, there's no half measures with this, even with updating documentation people will still use `.run()` in production; best to nip it in the bud.

app should no longer have the method

I suggest add a comand line tool:

create a project

```
flask init
```

run local server

```
flask runserver
```

and so on

I'm strongly -1 on removing `app.run()`. True, some people use it on production, but what's going to prevent people from running `flask runserver` on production as well?

I don't oppose having an alternative method of starting the application that eliminates the need to issue the `app.run()` altogether, but removing `app.run()` just like that seems wrong to me. Just add a warning to it, make it as scary as you want, but don't break a workflow that people have been using for ages. If you guys feel strongly about removing it, then do it properly, start by deprecating it (scary message) and wait 2-3 releases to actually remove it.

Also, having access to a method that starts the application is useful for certain kind of tests. An example is when you want to run tests with Selenium, where you need a real server running. See how I do it [here](https://github.com/miguelgrinberg/flasky/blob/579ecd9435b392df114110985f514ad173a315f2/tests/test_selenium.py#L48). Obviously this can be implemented differently if `app.run()` didn't exist, but I think it is convenient and super simple to do it this way.

Regarding renaming `run()` to something else, I think it achieves little. At the end of the day, this is just a sequence of letters. Name it whatever you want, but you'll always have people that will find it way more easy to use that instead of gunicorn, uWSGI, etc.

> First of all their naming implies that, they are used for running a Flask application, they aren't. They are for running a Flask application during development, a subtle but important difference that causes significant confusion. Apart from that though, running a Flask application is never what you want.

What about just adding a big shiny warning message when starting an app using `run`, telling people that it should not be used in production. Just completely removing it would hurt Flask in the long run I think, because it would be a pretty backwards incompatible change, outdating a lot of documentation and articles about Flask.

> app should no longer have the method
> I suggest add a comand line tool:

Although off-topic, I personally like that flask is not opinionated about which project structure you should use. So I am not in favor of adding a tool that tells people how to structure their app. Also, we already have something like [cookiecutter](https://github.com/sloria/cookiecutter-flask) for that purpose.

Just my two cents.

> What about just adding a big shiny warning message when starting an app using run, telling people that it should not be used in production.

Should have a kwarg to disable it (or possibly an env var). It's really annoying to see the same message over and over. Just like the "be careful while driving" nonsense GPS devices in cars show at every startup you end up hating it.

it would be enough to name it `run_insecure_devserver` (which is a propper description) where its suddenly very apparent that such a method shouldnt be on the app
there is nothing wrong with having a api to do it, its wrong to have one thats easyly missused and abused

`run` is dead, long live `flask run`.  Not that that actually "solves" this problem, but I don't think there's any foolproof way to protect users from themselves at this point.  I think we should close this.
Yeah. Run can hang around in the current form. We ship something better now :)
Should APP.run perhaps print a big warning
